subject: Cybersecurity
title: Children's Privacy: COPPA and Beyond
description: A fast breakdown of Children's Privacy: COPPA and Beyond for builders.

hook.text: A 10-year-old plays a free mobile game. The game collects location, contacts, browsing history, and voice.

buildup.text: COPPA (1998) requires websites to get verifiable parental consent before collecting data from children under 13 in.

discovery.text: Companies dodge COPPA by claiming their services aren't 'directed at children' â€“ even when millions of kids use.

twist.text: TikTok was fined $5.7 million for collecting data from children under 13 without consent. YouTube paid $170 million.

climax.text: Children's privacy laws haven't kept up with TikTok, Roblox, and Fortnite. Kids generate more data than ever with.

punchline.text: The game is free. The child's data is the product.

quiz.question: How do many companies circumvent COPPA requirements?
options: They claim their services aren't 'directed at children' despite millions of child users
They ask children for permission instead of parents
